185559440.review:
OK, so I've played this for almost 1400 hours. I can safely say...

HOLY SHIT. HOLY SHIT. It is the best strategy game I've ever played. So good, in fact, that instead of talking about my girlfriend (who, contrary to the girlfriends of many, would probably fucking love this game) or how much of my life I've wasted... I'm going to... *GASP!* Actually talk about the fucking game!

So, the game takes place from 1444 to 1821, though even your really good campaigns will probably last until about 1650 at most unless it's an achievement run or world conquest. You can expect a single campaign to be anywhere from 5 to 100 hours in length depending on the game speed you prefer, when you drop the campaign, your playstyle, the starting position of your nation and how good you are at the game (and/or how long it takes until you realize a run is utterly fucked, give up, and go play a campaign elsewhere or take a break from the game.) You play as one of many nations throughout the world, from the kingdoms of Western Europe and the princes of the Holy Roman Empire, just leaving the feudal age and starting to question the Pope, to Eastern Europe and the Balkans (yes, for all you Romaboos, Byzantium/the ERE is playable, but it is PAIN) where the Ottomans will soon sweep through on a path of conquest, to the Middle East and Africa where a variety of faiths, from the Sunnis and Shias of Arabia and Persia, where the Mamluks and Ottomans will conquer and the Timurids are about to fall, the Ibadis of North Africa, the Coptics in Ethiopia, and the squabbling between Muslims and African pagans (known as Fetishists in-game) throughout the continent. In Asia, Japan is about to experience the Sengoku, Ming China is having a golden age but can (and will) fracture at any moment with the hordes on its back, and India is full of empires whose networks of alliances will almost certainly frustrate you at every turn, and southeast Asia sees the fall of Srivijaya and the rise of such empires as the Ayuthaya. In the Americas, which if you're playing a mega campaign appear for the first time in this game, the natives form confederacies (referred to as federations in-game) and migrate aimlessly, unaware of what awaits them once the colonists (be they Europeans, Asians, or even Africans) come into their shores... And finally, Australia... The land down under is boring as fuck. 90% of us haven't played there because... It's literally just hundreds of years for waiting for colonists to arrive so you can actually do anything outside of Australia, and for what, Fetishism under a different name and the federation feature?

Conquest is the name of the game, gameplay wise. This is a map painter, after all, and whether you're playing tall and building cities that make Constantinople look like the rural ass town I'm currently living in or playing wide and building a vast empire, your goals will ultimately be focused on conquest to some degree or other. You build up your economy and mana points to support your conquests, and diplomacy, bar some places like the HRE and North America prior to the rise of federations, is all about who you want to conquer right now, who you can save for later, and who you can make into your loyal subject and annex peacefully. You tech up to make more money and have better soldiers than your enemies, you manage alliances and royal marriages to ensure you have more soldiers than your enemies and have an heir (though personal unions can be an amazing reason to royal marry as many big nations as you can if you're Christian, they have no heir and won't when their king dies, and feel you can fight whoever the strongest nation that isn't you and is married to them is), you click through events, missions, and ideas to build up modifiers to help you with all these things and more. 

However, it is a game where nothing of interest can happen for a while and you'll oftentimes need to wait for a golden opportunity to strike, before anyone else can (or at least before anyone else sieges down all the provinces you want because you can't take them once they do, though Europa Expanded, which I'd highly recommend as your first mod - more on those later - has an amazing QoL feature allowing you to take occupations from your allies in a war in return for favors, which is hella useful if you're like me and just want to chill and let the AI do its thing sometimes, or your armies are having their asses handed to them and your allies are doing amazing in comparison.) As such, if you're the type who gets impatient waiting for things to happen, go play a unit-based RTS like Age of Empires or Command and Conquer where the waiting game is much less significant, or just don't play RTS games, I dunno.



The graphics are... Not the best, but this came out over 10 years ago now. As a consequence, it will run on literally anything that isn't a shitty craptop with RAM in the megabytes in 2025, and even then GeForce Now runs it handily in a pinch (though don't expect mod support at all.) The music is amazing, with some of it being orchestral pieces, some of being rock - hell, there's even a couple Sabaton DLCs if you're fans of theirs. There's a few DLCs for sound that are basically a podcast explaining the history of the region at the time if you're boring like that, too.

Speaking of DLC... Unless they come out with another Humble Bundle or something along those lines for it, or you're willing to do things that, for legal purposes, I am not going to name and dare not recommend you do in the presence of GabeN and our almighty moderator overlords, do yourself a favor and buy the subscription. I got everything up to Leviathan for about $30 or so through one, and still ended up spending over $100 on DLC to own every major expansion. The absolute must buys are now built in, and a few small DLCs that add a few events or song tracks are dirt cheap, but the game feels empty without the major DLCs and total conversion mods are going to crash unless you have all of them purchased and enabled because pretty much all of them rely on the DLCs for something or other.

As for mods... Europa Expanded should be your first, if you intend on playing modded real early. It's a vanilla plus mod that overhauls everything while still being true to the vanilla game, with real love and care put into it. Once you're used to the game (I started playing modded at around 600-700 hours or so? But you could easily start playing total conversions at 300 or so if you really don't like the start date as is) I'd move onto the big total conversions. Ante Bellum, Post Finem, and Gods and Kings are all ones I'd recommend. Then you can get into lesser known ones - check Chewyshoot (also the Post Finem head dev)'s channel, he regularly reviews mods and a lot of the total conversions are relatively new. Of course, though, I'm gonna be a bit of a shill for a moment and recommend my upcoming mod, Terra Nihil - a modern day/fantasy dystopian alternate history where alien empires that seek to effectively vassalize the Earth, cabals of magicians wanting to bring about a society of magic, cults hell-bent on bringing salvation to everyone, by force if they have to, megacorps that seek to make a profit at all costs, and gangs so massive they may as well be their own states rule the day. Smaller mods also exist, with things ranging from basic QoL, to graphical changes (ranging from changing the font of the text to making all the flags into anime girls), to translation mods, so if you're looking for something a bit more vanilla and EE isn't your thing, those exist too.

All in all, if you're looking for a fun little time sink where you can conquer, colonize, and play out your wildest early modern era alternate history scenarios, EU4 is the game for you. If you're looking for something that's easy to learn or something you can just pick up and put down, though, you're better off looking elsewhere.

I have played HOI2, Vic2; my best friend mastered EUIV. It's a great game!

I played most of it without any add-ons and it's wicked. Don't listen to the others, the base game WILL keep you interested.

Then (after several, several hours) you'll start digging in.

I got all add-ons thx to EU4 about to become obsolete. Little changes. You can still definitely enjoy game mechanics like with Vic2 or Vic3; Hoi2; Hoi3 etc.

The only paid add-on I've always kept up to was music/soundtrack. This game delivers with what you pay for. I mean, in Victoria, the mods are taking over and no one ever can ever charge you for an obsolete perfect Bach pipe organ musical or Chopin piano romantic music. (THX Paradox!). In EU you'll pay, but it's well worth it. VERY GOOD soundtrack. Little quirks, like Fredman's Epistles funny bits became a part of mine and my missus lives.

Anyway. If you like strategies, like Transport Tycoon (OTTD); Civilisation (1,2,etc); C&C etc just buy the game. It'll take you a while to get it, but it's fine and the whole point of having it.

I am a strange guy, dealing with moving vehicles. All my live I've been fixing aircrafts so Transport Tycoon or Transport Fever 2 or Workers & Resources are on my agenda but after all (maybe because of my interest in history & politics) I've ended up playing EUIV in my limited time. After playing Civ2 in my childhood, this is a perfect strategy game for me. Takes time to master, yet simple and easy to logically understand after a while.

185341842.review:
This isn't going to be a review about paradox DLC policy, this is a negative review about the actual game

In short i simply don't recommend it if you're not already a veteran. The game has been tailored to be unbelievably hostile towards you, requiring tons of meta-gaming strategies and min-maxing just about every mechanic just to play the current state of the game, further reinforced by the newer content and DLC; It's intended for you to play with all these things in mind. It's essentially a tryhard competitive solo strategy game

There are also missions or unique functions that kind of break, as the way you were meant to obtain them is potentially nigh-impossible due to how key nations and great power AIs function now as well as the buffs and missions those nations have received

You should also note that the AI does in fact cheat and there is a bias towards you. Cheats are given to specific nations that were meant to represent their historical power, but they've instead become monstrous raidbosses to such unfathomable power that reduces your own agency and ability to control or set them against each other. Some of them are so powerful that they border on defying key mechanics

In summary, don't go in to this game because you want to roleplay and make your own history, setting your own borders and changing cultures or doing other things. This is gone by now. Play this game if you want a hardcore strategy game where you're leveraging everything the game offers to conquer as wide as you can

185301121.review:
I desperately want to like EU4. As a Crusader Kings III player with hundreds of hours in that game, I thought I would be able to play and enjoy this one to the same degree... but I just can't. The game feels extremely dated in nearly every aspect. Here are some of the things that I feel like worsened my experience:

1. WASD doesn't move the camera. You either have to use the arrow keys or mouse over the edge of the screen and there is no way to change this in the vanilla game.

2. The game doesn't really support resolutions higher than 1920x1080. The buttons were so tiny you could barely see them on the default settings, and there isn't a way to scale UI-- I just had to select 1920x1080 and deal with some parts of the game looking unclear.

3. The UI is clunky and unintuitive. There are nearly a dozen tabs that you have to be frequently clicking between, but to open them you need to first open the nation view menu before seeing those options. There are hotkeys, but the hotkeys only work if you opened the nation view menu first. Even when you get into the proper menu, the text in there is so small that it's hard to tell what you're clicking on or what is important when presented with a page full of numbers and symbols that weren't well-explained in the tutorial.

4. The tooltips are hit-or-miss. While some tooltips display useful information, other times some tooltips don't really tell you that much or are completely nonexistent. For instance, in one specific event, I had the option to gain a claim on Gascony. Because I was unsure where Gascony was, I did what I would do in CK3 and clicked on the name to try to open a separate page on Gascony and see it on the map. Nothing happened. I moved the event panel to the side and started searching the area where I roughly thought Gascony was for the province named after it. Also nothing. It turns out Gascony is not a province, but rather a region, and therefore it wasn't labeled on the map, but by the time I figured that out I had already picked a different option that was more clearly explained.

5. The popups get pretty annoying. Now, I know this must sound like a joke coming from a CK3 player considering how much that game uses popup events, but the main difference here is that I was getting popups about things happening in places that weren't my nation. Neighbor annexes a province? Pop up. Neighbor completes a decision? Pop up. Neighbor declares war on someone completely unrelated to me? Pop up. All of these things could be useful in very specific situations, so I see why having that information relayed to you is important, but why does it have to open a menu you have to click "OK" on? At least in CK3, full screen popups with things completely unrelated to you are rare, and they are primarily reserved for things that directly affect your character or nation. Other information, such as neighbors declaring or winning wars is still listed on your screen, but in a smaller log in the bottom right that doesn't force you to stop what you're doing and confirm you read it. Maybe there is a way to change this in-game, but I couldn't find that setting if there was one.

I absolutely love the concept and time period of EU4, and the gameplay seems interesting, but I've found that it is impossible for me to enjoy it with just how dated, unclear, and clunky it feels. Unfortunately, issues like the ones I listed above are preventing me from liking it. Maybe it's a skill issue, and if clocked as many hours in this game as I have in CK3 I'd be used to working around all these issues, but I feel like getting to that point would feel like a chore to me.

I don't think EU4 is necessarily a "bad" game, it just has some aspects in it that make it really unapproachable to a new player, even a veteran of other Paradox games. I think if you took the time to work through these issues, reorient yourself to the older controls, and accept that the game isn't going to give you all the information you need in-game, it could be enjoyable. But, I'd personally rather not spend my time forcing myself to play a game for a chance of having fun in the future when I could rather be playing games I'm certain I enjoy.

185207360.review:
Europa Universalis IV Review

Europa Universalis IV is a grand strategy game that immerses players in the intricate web of global history, diplomacy, and conquest. However, it comes with both remarkable strengths and notable drawbacks. Here’s a detailed breakdown:

Cons
Bottom-line Cost
The initial cost of the base game might seem reasonable, but to fully experience all the game has to offer, you’ll need to purchase a significant number of DLCs. These expansions introduce essential features, mechanics, and content, making the base game feel incomplete without them. The combined cost of all the DLCs is steep, making it one of the most expensive games to fully enjoy. For new players, this can be a major deterrent, especially when compared to other games in the genre.

Too Much Expensive DLC
Paradox Interactive, the developer, has a reputation for releasing frequent DLC packs. While these updates keep the game fresh and engaging for long-term fans, they create a barrier for new players. The sheer volume of DLC can be overwhelming, and the high price tags for each expansion make it difficult for players on a budget to access the full experience. Players often find themselves deciding between an incomplete experience or investing heavily.

Tedious to Learn
Europa Universalis IV is not a pick-up-and-play game. Newcomers are faced with an overwhelming array of menus, systems, and mechanics. Understanding diplomacy, trade, warfare, and internal politics requires patience and a willingness to research outside the game. Even the tutorials often fall short in adequately preparing players for the full experience. This can make the game feel more like work than entertainment at the start.

Very Technical and Difficult to Manage
Once you begin playing, the depth of the game becomes both a blessing and a curse. Managing your nation involves monitoring countless details, from trade routes and alliances to troop movements and cultural unrest. For players who thrive on micromanagement, this is engaging, but for others, it can feel overwhelming. The technical aspects can lead to frustration when a single oversight spirals into a cascade of failures.

Steep Learning Curve
Even for seasoned strategy gamers, the learning curve is daunting. Mastering the game requires hours of trial and error, consultation of guides, and repeated playthroughs. Unlike many modern games that ease players in gently, Europa Universalis IV throws you into the deep end almost immediately, making it feel inaccessible for casual gamers.

Takes Too Long to Finish a Game
A single campaign in Europa Universalis IV can take dozens, if not hundreds, of hours to complete. While this is a testament to its depth, it also means that committing to a game is a significant time investment. For players with limited free time, completing a campaign is a challenge, potentially leading to frustration when progress feels slow or when real life interrupts gameplay.

Pros
Learning About History
Europa Universalis IV is one of the most effective games for teaching history through gameplay. Players are introduced to real historical events, figures, and dynamics, such as the Protestant Reformation, the colonization of the Americas, and the rise and fall of empires. Even players with a casual interest in history will come away with a deeper understanding of the world's complex past.

Watching History Unfold Before Your Eyes
The game’s dynamic mechanics allow players to rewrite or mirror history. Watching the ebb and flow of nations as you guide your chosen country through centuries of global change is mesmerizing. Unexpected developments, such as the rise of a minor nation or the collapse of a major empire, make each playthrough unique and engaging.

Engaging Gameplay
Despite its complexity, Europa Universalis IV is deeply engaging once you understand its systems. Every decision feels impactful, and the game rewards strategic thinking and careful planning. Whether you’re negotiating alliances, waging wars, or managing internal crises, there’s always something demanding your attention and challenging your intellect.

Transportative Experience
Few games are as immersive as Europa Universalis IV. The detailed map, historical events, and intricate mechanics create a world you can lose yourself in. The game captures the feeling of being a ruler navigating a turbulent era, making it easy to forget you’re playing a game and not orchestrating real-world history.

Older Game, but Still Holds Up
Originally released in 2013, Europa Universalis IV remains a benchmark for grand strategy games. Its consistent updates and community support have kept it fresh, and its depth and polish continue to outshine many newer titles. The game’s longevity is a testament to its quality and the dedication of its developers and fans.

Final Thoughts
Europa Universalis IV is a game that rewards patience and dedication. It offers an unmatched historical strategy experience but demands a significant investment of time, effort, and money. For those who love history and deep strategy games, it’s an essential title. However, casual gamers or those on a budget may find its barriers to entry too high to justify. If you’re up for the challenge, Europa Universalis IV offers a journey through history like no other.

185185036.review:
玩EU4最重要还是一个代入感。入门普通难度玩点无脑强的，比如奥地利和奥斯曼。玩个100年或者到厌倦的时候再换其他的大国和中型国家，然后再尝试一下小国破局。之后再玩玩大国极难基本上就入门了。在之后不自虐（小国极难之类的）基本上都随便玩了，玩起来就靠一个代入感，不然随便玩个50多年都知道滚雪球下去肯定能一直赢之类的。

代入感一部分靠任务树，另一部分就靠脑补了，打之前先看看该国的巅峰历史，然后就想着复刻一下这段历史；不过看了看真实历史，你就发现EU4的模拟还是差的太远了，这时候一方面你可能会去找拟真mod，比如Common Universalis、Meiou&Taxes、欧式和平等等。这种mod要么真就很拟真，搞得操作极端复杂。要么是强行在原版上加ex机制让扩张难以进行。不过也可能有相应的受众吧；另一方面，你又想玩点狂的mod，就可以整个诸如天朝日不落、归墟之门之类的。这种有时候又搞得太强索然无味了；当然还有架空类的mod，比如战争前夜、什么别的世界的mod等，这种就偏原版。

然而你玩完那么多mod，就会发现，还不是为了体验一个强的tag，需要的就是机制、就是狂派mod（现实也是很狂派的）。最终还得是——《归墟之门》，有滥强的tag（里加等），也有地狱难度的tag（可以主动作死开极难，也可以选择灾难不断的伊比利亚公社等tag），难度范围大，机制多，且某种意义上合理（比如萨法维，原版如何可能达到历史崛起速度?）整活也多。

无论怎么玩，入门后EU4还是很杀时间的，建议注意游戏时间。

新人玩推荐西班牙奥地利或者大明，西班牙可以体验到殖民，有DLC的话还可以随机新大陆，可以体验到自己的殖民地慢慢变大并且给你打钱提供军队上限，不过新手第一次玩后期可能会担心殖民地独立倾向，其实那个只要自己够强就不用担心，同时这个过程中对土著一次又一次的胜利游戏体验应该还是很好的。另外西班牙也可以慢慢研究一下贸易系统，贸易在这个游戏中是很重要的收入来源。
奥地利可以体验外交，呼叫队友来帮忙打败强敌并且联合统治很多强国，看着自己的小弟自动打败敌人，神罗系统还可以让你附庸全部神罗国家且不占外交关系数量，就可以获得更多自动打仗的附庸。
大明就是单纯的强大可以让你自由发展熟悉游戏，即使你不那么激进也不会落后其他人很多。
奥斯曼很强不过不熟悉游戏的话容易因为一些决策失误产生一些焦虑感。

185158485.review:
It's quite good....
Kidding, I played for 1.6k+ hours basically without ever touching mutliplayer (like 5 hours played with friends) and I can say it is a great game with great accuracy. It is Grand Strategy very deserving of the word "Grand".

I had played EU3 for several hundred hours before getting EU4, so I had a head start on mechanics and it still took several hundred hours to find all the mechanics possible and involved. I am very much relying on experiences and going similar routes so I might take longer to find everything, but I distinctly remember finding a mechanic after like 300+ hours of gameplay that would have solved issues I had hundreds of hours earlier. And I still enjoyed the earlier playthroughs.

For someone starting the game, do not be afraid of starting low (in terms of difficulty and country selection) and it can feel overwhelming, but especially in lower difficulty, even with little/ few things a lot can be accomplished, especially with some of the historically "easier"/ better situated countries. 

Learned about the family "de Trastámara" only through this game and as someone interested in history, there is loooaaads in this game giving ideas what to look at and I have never found inaccuracies (unless in active gameplay as it's randomized to a degree). Not saying there are none, but they seem pretty rare at most.

I don't even consider myself very drawn to these type of games or only to a certain degree, as they always have aspects too annoying for me to handle (as an example here: naval combat, colony warfare, wars against other competing nations). To be clear: I don't think it isn't well done, just too tedious for me to handle.

I have seen many, many changes to the game as I have actively played it close to release and on and off until today and I would argue that in terms of realism, options and others it is today the best it's ever been. In terms of getting achievements it got "worse"/ harder in the very beginning. (Ryukyu anyone?) 

I have never liked not starting after the original starting point, partially because I am set in my ways when it comes to games, partially because when I did a couple of times, at the time the ideas the countries had, were more or less set in stone unless you wanted to lose a ton of progress and play catch up and not played a colony country or the pirates, not even really played through the Japan stuff and more. So yeah, it is a huge game and loads of fun.

184664050.review:
TLDR; Game is very complex, and you can have a lot of fun, especially with mods, however, this game became paradox money cow, there is a ton of shitty dlc's worth 10% of it's original price, the game becomes very laggy and painfull to play after 1600+, especially if you know how to scale, you can play with friends, but at low game speed and a lot of desyncs, for anyone new, i recommend to wait for EU V, if there will be such game


Although i really enjoyed it, and played a lot, at this point, I cannot recommend this game, especially for new players 

Regarding DLC's and paradox policy, overall cons of the game:

1. Most of dlc's actually add a joke amount of content that's worth around 5-15hours of average modder work with a beer over a weekend, as a matter of fact, there are mods that add gigantic amount of content, that's beyond compare with what paradox adds.
2. Price for these funny dlc's are actually enormous, most of dlc's is around 22 dolars on average in my country, 2-2 D O L A R S. And for those who is gonna say, yes but on sales you can buy each of them for 5 dollars - actually half of those dlc's are worth 5 dollars, not each one, and for the "newer ones" they actually don't go on sales, because why would they, it just add one mechanic, so pay these thieves for it, or you can simply buy some UltImAtE ExTrA bUnDlE that's around 40 dollars, to get whatever you don't have at the moment.
Ah, and just to be clear, my point of view on dlcs is simple, to charge 22 dollars for a dlc, make this dlc complex enough, to actually charge that 22 dollars, give something more, than what a modder can make over a weekend
3. DLC Subscription - it's actually a joke, that you have to pay 10 dollars a month, to just have access to these shitty dlc's, no, it's not worth it, even I'm gonna say it, it's better to pay for that UlTiMAtE ExTrA bUnDlE. 
4. Game Engine - and this is what, I'm angry the most, because if you have paid your 200 dollars for dlc's or whatever amount you had to in your region, learned how to play and actually scale in the game, you might wanna play a bit longer, than 100 years in game (You even might to decide to actually play with your friend! However its irrelevant for this point), then you gonna realize real quick, that the game is pain to play after 1600(however, the better you are, as a player, quicker you will have problems with how laggy the game becomes, and I'm speaking as a owner of ryzen 7 5700 x3d, and rtx3070, so not too bad setup)
And actually there is not a single one dlc, or any updates that comes with anything, that would help with how laggy the game becomes. 



So as i have yapped enough, let's move to pros:

1. The game is very complex, I have to admit that and if you are a new player, you are going to spend a lot of hours to learn mechanics, also those hidden in the game, overall it might at first reject some new players, as this game takes around 50 hours to play "freely"
2. Very advanced scene of modders, there are actually a lot of mod's that gives you basically different game, can give you possibility to play in 900years+ or enchance graphics (with btw. paradox should take care of that, especially after looking at the prices of the dlc's)
3. When you learn how to scale basically any country, it is really fun and rewarding.

And what I'm not sure is a con, or pros, I'm gonna say, that game allows you to play with your friends, but prepare to a lot of desync and overall you can't play with speed higher than 3 and in the later stages of the game, you might even have to sometimes slow down to speed 2 (which is a disaster, taking into consideration that we have 2025).

So, if you are a new player that's wonder if it is worth buying, I recommend to wait for EU V, if we will have such game, because who knows, maybe paradox plans to add dlc's for another 5 years.
If you really want to try this game, wait for sales, try to buy any bundle that gives you all expansions dlc.

Oyunda 200 saatim var ve görüşlerim şu şekilde bence Europa Universalis IV (EU4), strateji oyunları sevenler için eşsiz bir deneyim sunuyor. Tarih, strateji ve diplomasi gibi unsurları seviyorsanız bu oyun tam size göre. Ancak sabırlı olmanız ve karmaşık mekanikleri öğrenmeye zaman ayırmanız gerekiyor.

Eğer strateji oyunlarına ve tarihsel simülasyonlara ilginiz varsa, EU4 sizi saatlerce ekran başında tutabilir. Özellikle kendi alternatif tarihinizi yazma fikri gerçekten cezbedici. Örneğin, Osmanlı ile Avrupa'yı fethedebilir veya bir Kuzey Afrika devletiyle Akdeniz'de büyük bir ticaret imparatorluğu kurabilirsiniz.

Ancak oyunun öğrenme eğrisi gerçekten dik. İlk başta kafa karıştırıcı gelebilir, ama rehber videolar ve topluluk içerikleri bu süreci kolaylaştırıyor. Ayrıca DLC’lerin oyuna derinlik kattığını düşünsem de, tam deneyim için bir miktar masraf yapmanız gerekebilir.

184400897.review:
九年前入的正版，算上学习版也玩了十年了，将近2000个小时。这十年随着时间的推移，游戏变得越来越完善越来越复杂，p社游戏也从相对小众变成现在连up主们都一代新人换旧人换了一茬又一茬了。我也不再是当年那个窝在宿舍里，一边喝冰可乐一边一遍一遍的尝试着大明的西化和拜占庭破局的大学生了，也不再是那个想玩到几点玩到几点，时间看起来无穷无尽，未来有着千万种可能的我了。当年的我就像是1444的我，现在的我就算不至于1821那么夸张，1500也差不多了，地理大发现时代行将结束，拜占庭大概率已经亡国，勃艮第想必已经被瓜分，能改变的虽然还有很多，但失去的机会也着实不少。
感觉这游戏就像是人生，本来没什么目的和意义，都是要自己给自己立目标找意义，这一把我要用海西成立大清，下一局我要用法鸡重建罗马，有了意义和目标人们才会打开eu4玩下去，但人生的目标和意义好像没那么容易找寻，eu4可以开启无数把，甚至可以试遍所有的可能性，可以随意选择开局国家，或贫或富，地理所在，开始年份。人就不一样，人只能活一把，出身也完全随机，能掌控的太少，甚至不像游戏可以停下来思考，现实世界中停下来思考也是采取的一种行动和做出的一个选择，永远无法超脱事外。
人是天生寻求意义的生物也是天生寻求确定性的生物，因此在这过去的十年每每在现实生活中被虚无感和不确定性折磨的焦头烂额的时候我都会选择回到eu4来上一把，享受这种目标明确，反馈及时，注定成功的感觉。某种意义上来说，人所追求的极致就是eu4, eu4就是人间正道。
2025年了，希望新的十年我能找到我的意义。

184245181.review: EU4可以说是我第一款游戏，我也是先玩文明时代解馋。我是看资深小狐狸入坑的，再加上以前B站的看海，感觉这游戏真的好玩。我每次都随着视频幻想，自己建功立业、征服四方。后来高二我爸把旧电脑给了我，当时我有了点Steam的概念，确实想买，但接连碰壁，没有成年，没绑定银行卡，最关键的是没钱。最后从贴吧上下了个D版玩，直到高考结束后，我才买下来。初中时候，我玩完文明时代，就找到了E社的游戏，怎么我小半辈子全花在了策略游戏上了哈哈。彼时E社还处于最辉煌的年代，欧陆战争4，将军的荣耀3、世界征服者2，都是个顶个的好游戏。我发现他们，可以说是沾了EU的光。可以这么说，EU就是我游戏的启蒙。我现在游戏的导向全是被EU带的。我小时候可是CF枪王，要不是EU，我已经在打上海major了（笑）。EU从小时候我发现它起，就永远和我绑定在一块了。等我以后老了，我一定会让我儿子玩的，科技发展迅速，就让儿子在VR里开模拟器玩，我以后也会一直玩的......直到永远。就像那些老板在网吧里玩传奇一样，我老了就去那玩EU，好歹不会像玩传奇一样被嘲讽，因为他们看不懂。

184217498.review:
Знаком с EU4 ещё года с 18, большую часть часов наиграл именно в то время, решил установить её сейчас, посидел пару часиков и устал. Понимаю, что после HOI4 эта игра не подходит мне, хотя она очень хороша. Множество функций, настроек, параметров, дат начала кампании, стран, путей развития делают её ценнейшим кладом для любителей стратегий, но именно это и стало отталкивающим фактором для меня, не захотелось долго разбираться в этом многообразии аспектов. Есть только 2 пути: либо Europa Univerlalis 4 вам очень понравится - вы зависните в ней на 1000+ часов, либо она покажется излишне нагруженной и надоест через 15-50 часов, другого выбора не дано. Если исходить из моих воспоминаний - раньше играть с друзьями в неё было весело, поэтому рекомендую!

Плюсы:
1) Огромная вариативность всего
2) Адекватная стоимость по скидкам
3) Безграничный простор для фантазии
4) Поддержка модов
5) Золотая середина по сложности среди игр Paradox 

Минусы:
1) Завышенная цена без скидок
2) Зависимость контента от DLC
3) Устаревший дизайн

Нейтральная составляющая:
1) Нужно потратить много времени, чтобы разобраться во всех тонкостях игры.

184011712.review:
As a Hearts of Iron and Stellaris veteran, EU IV is exactly what you expect. If you like those two, you'll probably enjoy EU IV. You're taking charge of a country during the age of exploration. The base game is very heavily focused on Europe (with largely generic content for Asian, African, and Native American countries) but the DLCs make non-European countries a lot more playable.
I'd get the game on-sale with the starter bundle. The current base game already contains merged DLCs (same practice they did with HOI IV) but the the starter bundle gives non-European countries (particularly American natives) more content.
Admittedly though, the sheer number of DLCs are intimidating, but most of them are just cosmetic packs that goes along with actual "content" DLCs. Play the game first before deciding which DLCs to buy.

183890020.review:
I bought the ultimate bundle for myself for Christmas and I am disappointed to find that this game has frequent crashes on Mac since the 1.36 update which was released in 2023!
These crashes have been documented on various forums including the official paradox forums. They occur in specific scenarios when making a peace deal (Byzantium seems to be the main cause but other peace deals can cause this crash).
I have tested this by converting an Ironman save where the crash was occurring to non-ironman and tag switching to Byzantium then once I complete the peace deal then instant crash - seems like a memory leak (SIGSEGV) from the crash logs.

I am a veteran paradox games player (HOI4, CK2, IR, Stellaris) and have never had any issues with those games. So I am hugely disappointed to discover in the lack of attention to a well documented [b] [u] game breaking bug [/u] [/b].
( as well as the paradox dlc policy lol).

The game itself, once you learn the systems, is fun however I cannot recommend it in this state to Mac OS users.
I am a developer myself and spend 3-4 hours debugging this when I should've been on holiday.
Once this is fixed I will remove this review and post a positive one.

183566364.review:
This game is dear to me because it is the first Steam game I ever bought. I have played this game many times throughout my near-decade long stay here on Steam, and I can confidently say this game is great. Where it leaves off, its countless mods of varying sizes pick up. I really enjoy exploring the seas as Portugal, conquering the New World as Spain, and dominating the globe as the Ottomans. The list goes on.

If there is one complaint that I would have, it would be the daunting DLC section. Even if you were to own them all, you can't help but look at this egregiously long list of DLCs and be understandably put off by it. It is not friendly for new players of the game who are looking to experience the game at its best, and it is something I genuinely hope PDX fixes when they release the long-awaited successor for this game.

183550585.review:
In a genre oversaturated with greatness, Paradox should be proud of themselves for making the greatest strategy game ever made. Having slavishly bought every DLC on release for the past god knows how many years, I've been with the game through the rough patches and the good patches and I can confidently say that EU4 is in a great spot and if you care even slightly about strategy games you should pick it up. The game seems to be winding down in development as work on EU5 is picking up, so if you haven't gotten into the Europa Universalis series it's a perfect time to hop on, as the game seems to finally be well and truly complete. 

Endless possibilites await you and no two games are the same. You're looking at a game where some crazy Swede said that you should be able to play any country (within reason, calm down liechtenstein enthusiasts) in the world from 1444-1821 and they actually walked the walk. Even the countries with the most barren content usually has fully unique or shared unique national ideas, unique government reforms, some unique culture and religious mechanics, leaving for a truly staggering amount of content. Even in the nations themselves there are usually several different routes to go down. If you somehow find yourself not knowing what to play or what to do, there are almost 400 achievements to hunt down and in classic paradox fashion they range from accomplishing some stupid whim that a developer thought of in the break room, to some genuinely crazy feats which you can then slap on your profile and feel proud of. 

Is the game perfect? No, the game has some pretty obvious flaws. Paradox' balancing team constantly throws darts at a board and impliments it into the game, leading to some pretty hilarious situations like humanist dodging the most well deserved nerfs to this very day. Hordes too are for some reason still as broken as the day they released, if not more so, and still Siam gets nerfed every other patch. The mission trees are fun to play around with, but if we're being honest it's just modifier stacking for doing stuff you're actually going to do in a normal playthrough. Modifier stacking has also gotten seriously crazy over the years, but it can be kinda hilarious at times so it's not a true downside.

The DLCs and the pricing is always a hot topic when it comes to paradox games, and this one is not exception. Truthfully there's way too many of them, and the pricing has gotten arbitrarily raised so I understand why people get angry about them, but I still buy them on release. Paradox is quite possibly the last AA game company left on the market and as much as I can grumble about the price, I also understand that they have to run a tighter ship than triple A companies. They do at the very least go on large sales very frequently, so they're easy to get eventually.

I would be crucified if I didn't mention the modding scene, even if I feel like it shouldn't be mentioned in a review of the base game. There's mountains upon mountains of mods for this game and a lot of high quality stuff can be found on the workshop, so if you finally get bored of the base game after putting 173845 hours into the base game, rest assured that you can commit human rights violations in an alternate reality, or another world entirely. 

EU4 is the perfect game to waste 3000 hours, and then waste another 3000 hours for good measure.
